speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me when you first noticed any changes on your left dorsal hand, such as redness, itching, or a rash?

speaker: Patient
text: Well, to be honest, it was just a couple of weeks ago when I noticed this rough, scaly texture on my hand, and at first, I thought it might be dry skin from all the sun I've been getting from my daily walks, but it's been feeling fine and not itchy or painful.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you describe the area of the left dorsal hand that's affected? Is it a specific spot or a larger patch of skin?

speaker: Patient
text: It's a pretty small patch, actually, maybe about the size of a quarter, and it's located just above the wrist, on the top of my hand.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if the affected area on your left dorsal hand is itchy, painful, or does it have any other unusual sensations when you touch it?

speaker: Patient
text: To be honest, it's not itchy or painful at all, but when I run my fingers over the rough texture, it feels a bit... rough, like sandpaper.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of your symptoms, let's proceed with the examination. Can you please show me the affected area of your left dorsal hand so I can get a better look at it?

speaker: Patient
text: I'd be happy to show you. (holds up the left hand, pointing out the affected area) It's right here, just above the wrist.

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you show me the exact location of the affected area on your left dorsal hand - is it near the wrist, the thumb, or somewhere else?



Please point out the area so I can examine it thoroughly.

speaker: Patient
text: It's right above the wrist, where the top of my hand meets the back of my wrist. You can see the rough, scaly texture right there, just like I showed you before.

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me when you first noticed any changes on your left dorsal hand, such as redness, itching, or a rash?



Doctor: I'm going to take a closer look at the affected area. Can you please extend your left hand so I can examine it thoroughly?



Doctor: Now, I'm going to gently press on the affected area to see if it's tender.

speaker: Patient
text: It feels a bit firm to the touch, but not tender at all, I can still feel my fingers moving freely underneath.

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me if the affected area is more tender to the touch in certain directions, like towards the wrist or the thumb?



Also, I'd like to know if you've noticed any sensitivity to temperature changes, like it getting hot or cold in that area.

speaker: Patient
text: I think it's more tender towards the center of the patch, but not significantly so. And as for temperature sensitivity, I do notice that the area feels warmer than the rest of my hand, but that's about it.

speaker: Doctor
text:
I'd like to request a test to get a better look at the affected area: REQUEST TEST: Dermatoscopy.

Also, can you tell me how long you've been experiencing these symptoms, roughly a week or two?

tests:

text:

text:

text:

speaker: Patient
text: It's more of a dull, scaly texture, like sandpaper, but not red or inflamed. And I don't experience any discomfort or pain when I move my hand or apply pressure, just the feeling of the rough texture.

tests:
